story:
BONUS PERK UPDATE: Get your dream photo shoot donated by Ashli Akins when you donate $250 or more! (for Vancouver & Victoria, BC residents)

What is the challenge that Mosqoy needs help with?

In the Cusco region of the Peruvian Andes, indigenous Quechua communities face a challenging decision: to develop economically towards a prosperous future or to revitalize their unique yet threatened culture. Because of the lack of opportunities, most communities in the region feel they must choose one or the other, as they have few options to accomplish both. Mosqoy works with Quechua communities to achieve a future where they are not forced to choose. Instead, Mosqoy presents community members with viable economic opportunities that can co-exist with the continuation of traditional ways of life. This is the central focus of Mosqoy’s work.

How is Mosqoy Creating a Positive Impact?

Andean Youth Program

Our goal is to assist in creating a positive generation of leaders, for the future of these communities. Through our Andean Youth Program, we’ve funded over 60 students from rural communities to attend post-secondary education. Our current students are now studying various trades in the nearest city of Cusco, to be able to eventually return to their communities, become employed, and give back through both skills and resources. They have immense potential to become positive role models for the next generation, and to turn this vicious cycle into a positive one. All they need are resources and encouragement.

Textile Revitalization Program

We support over 150 weavers to sell their traditional textiles at fair-trade marketplaces. These textiles are unique works of art and rich sources of Quechua heritage and wisdom. They act as a history book, documenting Quechua values, beliefs, and stories. Much like the salmon is a keystone species in biology, these textiles are a keystone species for their culture. Profits from sales support the Andean Youth Program, as well as socioeconomic development projects chosen by the communities, such as building compostable toilets and creating communal weaving centres.

Global Stewardship Program

Mosqoy works with elementary schools, high schools, and universities in North America to raise awareness and inspire future generations to become globally aware and responsible youth. These are, after all, the next backpackers and consumers of the world. If they do not know how to positively impact the communities they encounter, they may inadvertently cause negative impacts. Our goal is to build global stewardship and compassion, to shift globalization towards more positive outcomes.

 

Why We Need Your Help

  • Our programs have tripled in the last 7 years, and the passion and dedication of our volunteers is no longer enough to maintain our sustainability.
  • We are now supporting approximately 150 weavers and over 60 students in 15 highland communities of the Andean mountains. And there is a wait-list.

 

 

What will we do with your donation?

With $15,000, we can expand our programs AND create long-term positive change in the following ways:

1.     Hire staff in Peru to maintain our programs.

Our staff in Peru fill an irreplacable role in the lives of our students: they act as mentors, leaders, and sources of inspiration. We need to secure their funding to make sure our students can continue to benefit from their support.

2.       Expand our retail network and set up an online store

We have the supply and the demand. We just need the capital to be able to buy more weavings from our network of artists, to provide a steadier and more guaranteed source of income. With this, we can expand our outlets from fairs and festivals, to retail stores, boutiques, museums, and our very own online store. 

3.       Create a Short Documentary Video

 

The documentary will focus on our work in Peru, letting Mosqoy alumni and Quechua weavers speak for themselves. The film will also offer rare insight into the lifestyle and traditions of remote Andean communities.


4.       Kickstart our social enterprise programs

 

Mosqoy’s new social enterprises include partnering with retailers to expand our textile revitalization project and organizing educational tours for high-school students. These social enterprises will enable our programs to become more self-sustainable, as we’ll be able to fund our own programs.

 

5.      Put more energy into our programs, less into fundraising.

 

What have we achieved so far?

  • Over 60 students have been funded, and 27 have graduated, becoming nurses, eco-tourism guides and government employees.

  • 150 weavers have benefitted from selling their textiles fair-trade, using the funds to support their communities' own goals towards sustainable development.

     

More Reasons to Support Us

The Mosqoy model is designed to become self-sustainable through the communities we work with in Peru. Mosqoy Alumni will re-invest into the education fund after graduation, supporting future generations of students. Weavers will gradually set up enough capacity to develop local markets. With enough textile sales and program graduates, the youth of these communities will be running Mosqoy themselves! 

We are frugal and will use every dollar wisely.  For 7 years we have done a lot with very little; we know every low-cost alternative out there and have learned the most effective ways to make a lot of positive change happen.

We are a registered Canadian charitable organization. Meaning that we’re held accountable to our work.

 

How can you help?

  1. Donate!

     

    You will get perks, some of which include guided eco-tours of remote Andean communities, or Andean textiles (hand-woven, with all-natural fabrics and dyes). But even smaller donations will get you something special, as a token of our sincere gratitude.

     

  2. Can’t donate, or want to do more?

     

    Comment on our campaign page, share our updates or show our campaign video to friends at a party.

     

You are the key to the success of this campaign and we cannot do it without your support. Check out the 10 Easy Things You Can Do to Help Out and join us in making a change!

story:
Comic Girl Coffee & Books

A collective space. For us, by us.

My name is Lara Americo and I’m a transgender activist, artist and musician living in Charlotte, NC. I’m passionate about creating inclusive, positive spaces for communities, which I’ve done through my work with The Freedom Center for Social Justice Center and other local organizations supporting queer and trans people of color for the past three years.

On top of that, I’m a huge fan of reading and writing comics. Sequential art tells stories in a way that books can’t. In graphic novels and comic books, you have an intersection of art and writing that you don’t see in any other medium. Something powerful happens in that short moment when you see the expression on a character's face and you read their dialog. You can feel what the character is thinking. You become the character. I want to share this feeling with everyone.

The intersection of my community work and love of comics got me thinking: How many people who are queer or trans (or are bad ass cis accomplices) love comics and inclusive storylines but feel like they can’t share it with anyone in real time?

In Charlotte, there aren’t enough inclusive in-person spaces. And there’s a large population of underserved LGBTQ people: Nearly 90,000 LGBTQ people live in the Charlotte metro area, and 3.3 percent of people in North Carolina identify as gay, lesbian or transgender. That’s only the people who feel safe enough to publicly identify themselves in these surveys (via Gallup and UCLA Williams Institute Survey).

Even though we’re considered a metropolitan city and have this population, there aren’t enough inclusive spaces. Charlotte doesn’t have a LGBTQ Community Center. Charlotte “gayborhoods” are disappearing because of gentrification. Local comics events are generally geared towards cisgender white men and other communities are an afterthought.

The reality is: We won’t have any inclusive spaces unless we create them for ourselves.

This is why I’ve created Comic Girl Coffee & Books, a space to read, share comics, build community, and drink fresh, local coffee. There will also be food for sale along with books and other products. I’ve found a space for the coffee shop, but I need an extra push to officially launch it!

The Plan

I’m looking to fund initial start-up costs. This includes licensing and business fees, improvements on the space, decorations and furniture, initial inventory and equipment. Your contribution will also fund the following items to get this place opened:

  • Espresso machine
  • Coffee
  • Comics
  • Local pastries
  • Cold brew from Pure Intentions
  • Security deposit for first month’s rent
  • Business License

My plan is to open two pop-up locations in Petra’s Piano Bar and Advent CoWorking as a way to subsidize funding for a permanent location at Area 15. Area 15 is a DIY, small business incubator with a reputation for developing businesses. I plan to open my first location here as long as I can pay the security deposit and get the above items.

Comic Girl Coffee & Books will:

  • Source coffee and tea from local roasters and fair trade organic suppliers.
  • Source food from people of color, trans, queer, femme and immigrant providers.
  • Create a safe, joyful space for community comic book and coffee lovers.
  • The long-term plan for Comic Girl Coffee & Books is to expand as big as our community

 

In the future, as we grow, here are the benefits coming from Comic Girl Coffee:

 

  • Provide marginalized people with a way to create their own income and be a part of a badass business.
  • Support the transgender homeless shelter Trans.formation House in Charlotte, which is projected to open in early 2018. A percentage of profits from Comic Girl Coffee & Books will go toward supporting marginalized people through employee/owner opportunities and supporting Trans.formation House.
  • Work towards understanding oppression and anti-oppression and have literature available to support this. Sliding scale pricing will ensure people can access information about collective organizing, sustainable housing, homesteading and other topics even if they can’t afford it -- and some of our comic books.
  • Events can also take place in the space that benefit the community. Community organizers will be able to hold events like fundraisers and meetings.

Let’s make this happen! Comic Girl Coffee & Books will be the place for people who want to laugh and share their love of comics and inclusive stories over coffee. Building community in Charlotte is crucial, and I’d love for us to do that together.

If you have any other questions about this project, please reach out to me. I appreciate your contribution and can’t wait to welcome you into Comic Girl Coffee & Books once I reach my goal!

story:
Gracious Partners,

We are hoping and pushing to raise a total of $10,000 for this project. Our bare minimum was set at $6,000, but we are hoping you will partner with us to produce a state of the art aquaponics system and greenhouse. There are some adjustments to the system and greenhouse that we have realized would produce a better product that will serve as a motivation and stimulant to a health food movement in this food desert. Going beyond our minimum will help us do that! Please read on to learn more about the problem and our solution.

The Bonton Food Desert and Our Aquaponics  System

You have the opportunity to make an impact for a community in need. It will empower them to stand up against hunger and provide a healthy lifestyle for generations to come! Please come alongside us so that we can make a difference together!

The neighborhood of Bonton is one of the worst food deserts in Dallas and the US. That means that at least 500 people or at least 33 percent of the census tract's population resides more than one mile from a supermarket or large grocery store without the means to travel. For a Bonton resident to get groceries, they must take a bus for 1.5 hours, do their shopping, and haul their groceries 1.5 hours back. There simply isn't healthy food within the geographic and economic grasp of a "Bontonian." Thus, most grow up eating packaged snacks and french fries from the local beer&wine store and are suffering the health consequences. I met a man dying of kidney and heart failure at 41, and another going blind from diabetes in his 40's, not because of hereditary issues. Rather, they have had terrible nutrition since their birth. Quite a perdicament, right? Bonton's residents and HIS BridgeBuilders refuse to wait until somebody else solves their problem. They are embracing a plethora of urban farming techniques, one of which is aquaponics. Aquaponics is a system in which the waste produced by fish supplies nutrients for plants grown hydroponically, which in turn purifies the water for the original fish. It is an efficient system that has huge potential in helping this community! Here is a picture:

The first aquaponics system built in this community has been an enormous success. Many residents are working on it and reaping the benefits of its produce. The community is excited about how this can help provide healthy and affordable food for their families. However, with winter coming, the aquaponics system needs to be winterized by mid-October. That is where you come in!

By investing in this project, you will be an important part in our quest to saturate Bonton with fresh healthy food. We are using unique urban farming techniques to give fresh fruit and vegetables to Bonton's residents and to teach them how to replicate these systems for their families. One of these techniques is aquaponics, defined as "a system of aquaculture in which the waste produced by farmed fish supplies nutrients for plants grown hydroponically, which in turn purify the water." The aquaponics system has provided much needed produce to many in the community. However, the system will be extremely disadvantaged and almost completely fruitless (and vegetabless ;) if it is not protected against the coming winter weather. We desperately need to construct a greenhouse around our aquaponics system and winterize it to ensure year-around production. Your contribution will be a vital part of our success!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to continue providing this urban farming aquaponics system to the community throughout the winter. To that end, we need a greenhouse, a heater and other winterizing equipment to ensure the fish and produce from the system can continue to provide fresh, easily accessible, and healthy food to Bonton's residents. To pay for the equipment, labor, and cost of transacting here, we need $10,000. Here is a preliminary drawing of what the greenhouse will look like!

In order to keep with our theme of community restoration, we will acquire most of our building materials from Habitat Home restorations in the community. Furthermore, the building process of this greenhouse will intentionally include members of the community. They will be taught throughout the project and will take charge in some of the work. Furthermore, they will be some of the many beneficiaries of the system's produce.

We are committed to spending this money with integrity and wisdom (so much to do and so little resources to do it!). So, if we do raise more than our goal, 100% of all funds will enable other vital community farming projects. This greenhouse is but one of many things we are doing to saturate this food desert with the nutrition that its residents desperately need.

As a reward, we want to keep you involved and updated on this project. Check out the various reward levels to your right and please know that every dollar makes a HUGE difference! Please check out some perks to your right and get yourself involved in a great cause!

Other Ways You Can Help

Money doesn't grow on trees and you may not be able to give financially. However, you can still be a vital part of helping us reach our goals. Send this page to everybody you know via social media, email, and word of mouth. We need you to advocate for the provision of good food in this food desert!

One of these techniques is aquaponics, defined as "a system of aquaculture in which the waste produced by farmed fish supplies nutrients for plants grown hydroponically, which in turn purify the water." The aquaponics system has provided much needed produce to many in the community. However, the system will be extremely disadvantaged and almost completely fruitless (and vegetabless ;) if it is not protected against the coming winter weather. We desperately need to construct a greenhouse around our aquaponics system and winterize it to ensure year-around production. Your contribution will be a vital part of our success!
What We Need & What You Get
We need to continue providing this urban farming aquaponics system to the community throughout the winter. To that end, we need a greenhouse, a heater and other winterizing equipment to ensure the fish and produce from the system can continue to provide fresh, easily accessible, and healthy food to Bonton's residents. To pay for the equipment, labor, and cost of transacting here, we need $10,000. Here is a preliminary drawing of what the greenhouse will look like!


In order to keep with our theme of community restoration, we will acquire most of our building materials from Habitat Home restorations in the community. Furthermore, the building process of this greenhouse will intentionally include members of the community. They will be taught throughout the project and will take charge in some of the work. Furthermore, they will be some of the many beneficiaries of the system's produce.
We are committed to spending this money with integrity and wisdom (so much to do and so little resources to do it!). So, if we do raise more than our goal, 100% of all funds will enable other vital community farming projects. This greenhouse is but one of many things we are doing to saturate this food desert with the nutrition that its residents desperately need.
As a reward, we want to keep you involved and updated on this project. Check out the various reward levels to your right and please know that every dollar makes a HUGE difference! Please check out some perks to your right and get yourself involved in a great cause!


Other Ways You Can Help
Money doesn't grow on trees and you may not be able to give financially. However, you can still be a vital part of helping us reach our goals. Send this page to everybody you know via social media, email, and word of mouth. We need you to advocate for the provision of good food in this food desert!

story:
{English follows}

Il était une fois un petit restaurant

Depuis 2010, Edgar vibre au cœur du quartier Val-Tétreau à Hull, Qc. Restaurant couru pour ses brunchs, l’espace est rapidement devenu trop étroit pour la clientèle. Pendant des années, nous avons pensé déménager, mais le quartier est si difficile à quitter… En 2017, une chance s’offre à nous — devenir propriétaires de l’immeuble qui héberge le restaurant.

Cette campagne nous aidera à financer l’agrandissement du restaurant, qui passera d’une quinzaine à une quarantaine de places assises. En plus d’aider à couvrir les frais reliés aux travaux de construction, les fonds aideront à financer l’équipement nécessaire au fonctionnement de l’établissement.

 

Considérez cette campagne de sociofinancement comme un prêt fait avec amour :)

Vous pourrez vous procurer de la marchandise exclusive et à édition limitée Edgar, ou faire un investissement gourmand en vous procurant des cartes cadeau plus-plus, participer à des ateliers culinaires ou des événements qui titillent les papilles.

Une section de l’espace du restaurant sera dédiée aux commandes pour emporter : que vous soyez du quartier venu vous approvisionner en délicieuses pâtisseries, un.e cycliste en manque de caféine ou un.e travailleur.euse en pause-midi affamé.e pour un sandwich, le service de cette section sera plus rapide. Des tables hautes sont prévues, le temps d’engouffrer une brioche et un latté.

Vous désirez savourer un repas sur place? On vous accueille du côté salle à manger avec un service aux tables attentionné, typique Edgar. Une longue banquette permettra enfin de nous visiter entre amis et famille puis d’échanger autour d’une bonne bouffe.

L’immeuble étant d’un certain âge, les travaux de base à effectuer sont considérables — c’est pourquoi nous avons besoin de votre aide! Refaire les plafonds, les planchers, le système de ventilation, installer une poutre afin d’ouvrir le mur entre les deux sections, de nouvelles salles de toilettes… sans compter l’équipement de cuisine et le mobilier nécessaire pour se refaire une beauté!

Qu’est-ce qu’Edgar? Pourquoi nous aider avec cet agrandissement?

Edgar est une fierté pour le quartier, la ville et la province. 

Un petit resto de Val-Tétreau qui a souvent fait les rubriques gourmandes de revues (dont Ricardo, Véro, Taste and Travel, Clin-d’Oeil, L’Acualité…) et journaux (La presse, La Gazette, Ottawa Citizen, Le Droit…). Edgar s’est aussi taillé une place aux championnats culinaires canadiens en 2014 remportant la 4e place, et a emporté la première place au concours Gold Medal Plates en 2013. Des apparitions télé ont aussi fait rayonner Edgar  — entre autres au Food Network pour You Gotta Eat Here, aux côtés de Vincent Graton dans la série Le Goût du Pays, en compagnie de Benoit Roberge pour Sur Le Pouce, à la compétition culinaire À Couteaux Tirés de Chuck Hughes, et même une saison complète de 13 épisodes avec la chef Marysol Foucault pour Zeste tv.

Edgar est reconnu pour être bien ancré dans sa communauté — propriétaire et employé.e.s sont actifs avec Le Club des Petits Déjeuners, le CALAS, Harmony House, La société canadienne du cancer, la Fondation des Maladies du Cœur, Moisson Outaouais, Ten Oaks, Cultivating Cooks, Ottawa Food Bank ainsi que du bénévolat/mentorat dans certaines écoles ayant un programme culinaire. Marysol a également été porte parole officielle des producteurs d'oeufs du Canada en 2016 et 2017.

Votre aide est essentielle à la réalisation de ce projet. Grâce à vous, Edgar pourra enfin mieux vous accueillir. 

 

///

 

There Was Once a Tiny Restaurant

Situated in the heart of the Val-Tétreau neighbourhood in Hull, Edgar has delighted brunch crowds since 2010. The restaurant soon became too packed for its own good. For years, we searched for a new space but, the neighbourhood was too hard to leave… In 2017, the building owner finally gave us the opportunity we had hoped for and sold us the building. A new adventure was about to begin! 

This campaign will help us finance the renovations and equipment necessary to go from 13 seats to 40. 

Consider this a “loan with love.” :)
You can purchase exclusive (and limited quantity) Edgar merchandise, or treat yourself by investing in a gift card, cooking classes, or culinary events. We want you to look good and feel good! 

What will happen?
We will tear down a wall separating two spaces on the first floor. Half of the space will be dedicated to take-home meals, to-go lunches, pastry, and coffee. Whether you live in the neighbourhood and want pastries for your sweet morning at home, a cyclist in need of your caffeine fix, or work nearby and want a quick sandwich, everyone wins! Keywords: To go. Fast. We also plan some high tables for a quick bite. 

Not in a rush? Want to savour every little moment? We will then welcome you into our new dining room with the same warm and friendly service as always. This other half of the space will feature one long banquette to seat you, your friends, and family all together, finally! ;) 

The renovations will be extensive and that is why we need your help! The building being of a certain age, we need to bring in support beams to open up the walls, redo the ceiling and upgrade the ventilation system. And needless to say … we will need lots of new equipment to take care of all of you! 

What is Edgar and why help us with this expansion?
Edgar makes the neighbourhood, city, and province proud. This tiny, chef-owned restaurant has often made the cover of magazines and graced the pages of newspapers and cookbooks. Chef Marysol won gold at the 2013 Gold Medal Plates culinary competition and continued on to place fourth at the 2014 Canadian Culinary Championships. Edgar has been featured on the Food Network’s You Gotta Eat Here, with Vincent Graton in Le Goût du Pays, and alongside Benoit Roberge in Sur le Pouce. Chef Marysol also participated in Chuck’s Hughes televised culinary competition À Couteaux Tirés. Last but, not least, in 2017 Chef Marysol hosted her own 13 episodes cooking show, Les menus Zeste, on Zeste TV. 

Edgar is proud of its community involvement—we love The Breakfast Club, Harmony House, the Canadian Cancer Society, The Heart and Stroke Foundation (The Heart Institute), Moisson Outaouais, Ten Oaks, Cultivating Cooks, the Ottawa Food Bank, as well as, volunteering and mentoring in schools lucky enough to have a culinary program. In 2016 and 2017 Marysol has also been an official spokesperson for the Egg Farmers of Canada.

We need your help to make this project a reality. Thanks to you, Edgar will soon be able to welcome you with big(ger) open arms!

 

Un gros merci // A Big Thanks

Photo :: Christian Lalonde/Photolux

Photo :: Remi Thériault

Réalisation Vidéo :: Lévy L Marquis

Musique :: Vincent Freeworm

Vocal :: Alexandre Desilets

Narration :: Jean-Denis Scott-Bujold

story:
Short Summary

The North shore Cafe is located in the heart of White Salmon Washington in the beautiful Colombia Gorge. Our goal is to promote and inspire healthy active, artistic and thriving lifestyles throughout our community. We take pride in our hand crafted and holistic approach to our menu. White Salmon has been in need of the niche we have brought to this community... health conscious living. We are more than just your average cafe, along with delicious and nutritious food and a raw juice bar, we also serve as a creative outlet for this community. Each month we have a full calendar of events such as weekly open mic night, nutritional workshops and cooking classes, kids activities, acoustic crepe Sunday and much more.  Our goal is to increase health awareness through food, drink and artistic expression by taking our approach to the next level.
 I believe that we can change the world one community at a time. The healthier our communities are, the happier we are and as a result our world is a better place. It is time for us to purchase equipment that is industrial and energy efficient, so that we can increase the variety and production of our house made goods, along with offering more jobs and developing community outreach programs. We need your help! You can help by making a small or large donation to help us reach our goal of $20,000.  As a thank you we have a variety of gifts we will be offering! Please spread the word and help us reach our goal!

Please spread the word and help us reach our goal!

story:
All it took was a split second on August 18th 2012 for Brian Smith the marathoner, ex-football and rugby player to become Brian the quadriplegic. One last dive off the boat that day and Brian fractured his neck and almost died. After three months in an induced coma and continued rehab and occupational therapy, Brian is looking forward to what he can do, not what he can’t do.

Brian has a story. Some people may think that after what Brian has gone through, it might be a story of sympathy, loss and “why me?”. It’s just the opposite. It's a story of survival, perseverance, determination and what life can be. As mentioned in the Union Leader article below, Brian is striving to do what he can to get out of a wheelchair, not stay in one. If anyone has the chance in making that happen, Brian does. He has the spirit and determination and let’s face it, He’s just plain old stubborn!

Here’s where you come in. Rehabilitation is costly and much of it is not covered by insurance. We’re asking for your support so Brian can keep his focus on making progress, not how he’s going pay for what therapy. Whatever you can give is appreciated but please don’t stop there. Forward a link to this campaign to your family and friends. Post it on Facebook, Twitter or wherever. The more people that see it, the more money we can raise.

I’ll be posting a link to a Facebook page where we will have pictures and info from the "Fun Run" on August 18th and we'll updating everyone on Brain’s progress.

From Brain’s fellow Trinity Alumni, we thank you for your support.

 

July 21. 2013 8:39PM

Trinity grad to return to Manchester for ‘Fun Run’

By DALE VINCENT New Hampshire Union Leader

MANCHESTER -- BRIAN SMITH joined his family and friends at Lake Winnipesaukee this past weekend, as he has for years, but the 6-foot former marathoner now has to watch from shore when everyone else boards the boats to go out on the lake.

The 1983 Trinity High School graduate, who played football and rugby and worked as a construction equipment broker, was always in the midst of the action.
Until last Aug. 18, when he took one last dive off the boat and broke his neck.

Smith’s brother-in-law, Manchester Fire Department Lt. Glenn Jette, said no one noticed Smith go off the boat and he could have drowned.
“It’s a miracle,” said Jette, that somehow Smith was able to make it to the side of the boat. But Smith didn’t look good, so Jette asked: “Are you OK? Do you want some help?”

Smith’s brother, Daren, and a half-dozen others in the group with medical or EMT experience began working on him. The Moultonborough rescue squad neck-braced and back-boarded him for the helicopter flight to Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center. Smith survived.

The 48-year-old is considered a quadriplegic, with paralysis of arms and legs. He now lives in Arlington, Mass., in an apartment that is wheelchair accessible. A personal care attendant comes in daily to help.

But the man who ran seven Boston Marathons — five to raise money for the Jimmy Fund to benefit children with cancer — isn’t willing to settle. He’s determined to continue improving. He intends to get back on his feet.

Smith will be in Manchester for a special race this Aug. 18, exactly a year after his accident, when his friends hold a “Fun Run” to help with his progress.
Organized by Kevin Comerford, a friend since high school at Trinity, the 2.7-mile walk/run around Derryfield Park, is a chance to support Smith and his continuing efforts to regain mobility.

After three months in an induced coma and many more months of physical and occupational therapy, Smith believes he can make more progress toward independence.
“I’m moving my foot a little bit,” he said. He has some feeling in his hands, too.

Smith has been doing rehab with victims from the Boston Marathon bombing.
“Spaulding Rehab in Boston asked me to be a spinal cord injury mentor to patients at the hospital, which I gladly accepted,” he said.

But he is now focused on getting therapy at a nonprofit organization called Journey Forward in Canton, Mass. The program is not covered by insurance, but Smith said it is his best chance of continuing to improve mobility.

Instead of helping him adjust to life in a chair, he said, the goal at Journey Forward is to help him get out of it. Hand cycles and stand-up frames, electrical stimulation and other techniques are part of the program.

“It’s all about keeping the bone density up,” said the man who once ran as what he called a “Clydesdale,” a running category for big, bulky guys.
Daren Smith said his big brother was always a runner, trying to stay in shape. “That day ... of the injury, he ran up a big hill,” said Daren Smith.

The Aug. 18 event is planned as more than just a run/walk benefit for “Bubba.” It’s meant to be a social event as well. Everyone is invited to return to the school afterward to enjoy music, food and other refreshments, including beverages that can be brought by those taking part in the event.

The first 200 runners to register will receive a T-shirt. Registration begins at 7:30 a.m. at Trinity HIgh School, 581 Bridge St., and the race begins promptly at 9 a.m., rain or shine. The route starts and finishes at the Bridge Street entrance to Derryfield Park, across from Trinity, and loops around to Belmont Street and back, a total of 2.7 miles.

The route starts and finishes at the Bridge Street entrance to Derryfield Park, across from Trinity, and loops around to Belmont Street and back, a total of 2.7 miles.

story:
Short Summary

Please consider donating to Dream House – to help residents of the shelter with child care, legal fees, counseling, and medical expenses so that they can get back on their feet faster.

The high cost of childcare impacts all the residents of Dream House and makes it difficult for them to work towards achieving their goals to become self-sufficient.

Your gift will go a long way in helping to cover these essential expenses as they go back to school, enter the workforce, and strive for financial and emotional independence from their abusers.

Who We Are

Since 1995 Dream House has provided a safe haven for victims of domestic violence and human trafficking as they make a new start for themselves and their children in the Bay Area. The Dream Team is a group of 26 women who help by buying groceries and other necessities for the residents of Dream House as well as providing them with one-on-one mentorship. Dream House is a program of Jewish Family and Children’s Services, a Bay Area agency that helps children, parents, and seniors overcome challenges in their lives. 

The Impact

Residents of Dream House receive a safe home, counseling, and support to help them create a bright and self-sufficient future for their families. Our goal is to help residents leave Dream House and take the next step in their lives with stronger self-esteem, a network of support,  a secure place to live, and financial means of support. No resident leaves Dream House until they reach this goal.
story_txt: Short SummaryPlease consider donating to Dream House – to help residents of the shelter with child care, legal fees, counseling, and medical expenses so that they can get back on their feet faster.The high cost of childcare impacts all the residents of Dream House and makes it difficult for them to work towards achieving their goals to become self-sufficient.Your gift will go a long way in helping to cover these essential expenses as they go back to school, enter the workforce, and strive for financial and emotional independence from their abusers.Who We AreSince 1995 Dream House has provided a safe haven for victims of domestic violence and human trafficking as they make a new start for themselves and their children in the Bay Area. The Dream Team is a group of 26 women who help by buying groceries and other necessities for the residents of Dream House as well as providing them with one-on-one mentorship. Dream House is a program of Jewish Family and Children’s Services, a Bay Area agency that helps children, parents, and seniors overcome challenges in their lives. The ImpactResidents of Dream House receive a safe home, counseling, and support to help them create a bright and self-sufficient future for their families. Our goal is to help residents leave Dream House and take the next step in their lives with stronger self-esteem, a network of support,  a secure place to live, and financial means of support. No resident leaves Dream House until they reach this goal.

story:
MERCI A TOUS LES GÉNÉREUX CONTRIBUTEURS ! Nous avons atteint le premier objectif, mais CE N'EST PAS FINI ! Nous avons lancé en parallèle une collecte au Mexique et avons récolté pour 6 mois. Si nous atteignons 5 000 euros en France, nous aurons de quoi payer deux années de scolarité !

LUPE ET MAYA

Lupe a 6 ans et un sourire ravageur ; Maya, 7 ans et le charme d’une petite biche. Voilà trois ans déjà que nous côtoyons chaque jour ces deux rayons de soleil nés dans un bidonville mexicain.Toutes deux sont des indiennes mazahuas et parlent aussi bien l'espagnol que leur dialecte, une drôle de langue qui rappelle le japonais. 

Depuis la vieille Europe, on imagine que les enfants des barrios grandissent dans la violence, la drogue et l’abandon. C'est loin d’être toujours le cas. Lupe et Maya ont beau travailler le week-end dans les rues pour vendre du bois ou des tissus brodés par leur grand-mère, ce sont des enfants aimées et entourées. Avec leur coiffure toujours impeccable et leurs bonnes manières qui en ont déjà surpris plus d'un, elles observent avec émerveillement ce qui se passe autour d'elles et ne se lassent jamais de poser des questions. Certes, elles vivent avec toute leur famille dans une seule pièce, elles mangent des tortillas matin, midi et soir et se douchent avec un seau d'eau froide, mais c'est aussi ce qui leur donne le sens des réalités et surtout de la force.

Vous l’aurez compris : l’intelligence, l’assurance, la gaieté de ces deux petites filles brûlantes de curiosité nous ont séduits. Alors, au fil des mois, nous avons pris goût à leur apprendre à lire et à écrire, à leur donner de quoi dessiner, à jouer aussi… Seulement voilà, en août dernier, Lupe et Maya sont entrées à l’école, fières comme Artaban, prêtes à dévorer le monde. Mais l’école publique ici, ce n’est pas une panacée: cinquante-cinq enfants par classe, souvent pas de cahier et des cours de 13h30 à 18h tous les jours. Si vous ajoutez que, selon une étude récente de l'OCDE, 17 000 instituteurs dans le pays savent à peine lire et écrire...

Les chiffres sont alarmants. Sur 100 élèves qui entrent en CP, seuls 35 finissent l'école primaire. Quant aux enfants indigènes, 3% d'entre eux seulement parviennent à terminer le lycée. 

Maya et Lupe font de leur mieux, s’appliquent à l’école, ne manquent jamais de préparer leurs devoirs, mais dans ces conditions, leur avenir est déjà compromis. Dans un pays qui enregistre parmi les plus forts taux d'inégalité au monde, pour qu'un enfant pauvre puisse s'en sortir, il n'y a qu'une seule solution: l'envoyer dans une école privée. 

LE PROJET

Nous avons donc décidé d’aider Maya et Lupe à entrer à la Escuela Valle de Bravo, une école bilingue espagnol-anglais avec une ambiance familiale et des professeurs aussi attentifs qu’exigeants. Les propriétaires de l’école, après quatre jours d’essai, ont accepté de donner une bourse à nos deux petites protégées . C’est une grande première ! 

Directeurs, instituteurs, parents d’élèves, tous sont conscients de l’importance symbolique de l’entrée de Lupe et Maya dans ce petit paradis de l’éducation. Dans une société classiste et raciste, l’arrivée de deux indiennes dans des classes où la majorité des enfants ont le teint clair et des origines européennes est un chamboulement. Tous sont prêts à aider nos deux pionnières à s’intégrer tout en gardant les pieds sur terre. Tous considèrent que c’est une chance pour les autres élèves de prendre si tôt conscience de la diversité.

Plusieurs parents d’élèves ont déjà par exemple organisé une collecte d'uniformes déjà usés mais encore en bon état pour les offrir à Maya et Lupe. La future institutrice de Maya a proposé de lui donner gratuitement quelques cours de remise à niveau en mathématiques. 

Certes, l’idéal serait de changer radicalement le système éducatif au Mexique, de se battre pour l’amélioration des écoles publiques et de faire des campagnes contre le racisme, mais les petits ruisseaux font les grandes rivières. Si Lupe et Maya dans quelques années parlent couramment anglais et entrent à l’université, elles pourront alors défendre leur communauté. Si Lupe et Maya s’avèrent être un exemple d’intégration réussie, d'autres personnes seront à l’évidence tentées de se lancer au Mexique dans un projet similaire.

LE BUDGET

Nous avons besoin pour payer les frais de scolarité et le matériel de 3 600 euros par an, soit 1 800 euros par enfant. Vous trouverez la répartition des frais ci-dessous. Les frais de scolarité seront immédiatement payés à l’école pour bénéficier de 5% de remise supplémentaire et l’argent servant à payer matériel, livres et sorties, sera déposé sur un compte en banque spécifique dont nous aurons seuls l’accès. 

Le père de Lupe et Maya, Ramon, s’est engagé à donner 400 pesos par mois pour ses deux filles, l’équivalent de 25 euros. Il gagne 4500 pesos par mois, a quatre enfants à nourrir et ne peut vraiment pas faire mieux.

De notre côté, nous nous engageons à accompagner quotidiennement nos deux petites voisines, à leur donner des cours de soutien, à les encourager, mais aussi à vous donner de leurs nouvelles régulièrement: nous pensons publier une vidéo tous les six mois et peut-être créer prochainement un blog !

La collecte devra être renouvelée chaque année pendant encore 5 ans minimum jusqu’à leur entrée au collège. Si la somme de 3 600 euros est dépassée, l’argent sera conservé sur le compte en banque pendant un an afin de payer les frais de scolarité de l’année prochaine !

Prix initial

Réduction

Total

Lupe

Frais d’inscription

5 700

50% (bourse)

2 850

Scolarité

4 250  x 11 mois

25% (bourse)

23 375

Maya

Frais d’inscription

5 950

50% (bourse)

2 975

Scolarité

4 600 x 11 mois

25% (bourse)

25 300

Sous-total

54 500

5% (remise)

51 775

Matériel, livres, uniformes, sorties

15 000

-

15 000

Cours particuliers d’anglais cet été

(remise à niveau)

300 x 10 cours

3 000

Participation des parents

5 000 sur l’année

TOTAL

64 775

1 euro correspond aujourd’hui 16 mai 2015 à 17, 4 pesos. 

QUI SOMMES-NOUS ? 

Diego est un architecte franco-mexicain. Je suis traductrice, journaliste et écrivain et donne des cours d'Education civique et d'Initiation aux sciences politiques à la Escuela Valle de Bravo, au lycée, un jour par semaine. Cela me permettra de suivre de près l'année prochaine l'évolution de Lupe et Maya à l'école ! 

Nous vivons au Mexique depuis trois ans à Valle de Bravo, un village colonial situé au bord d'un lac à une heure seulement de la capitale. Nous avons construit notre maison sur les hauteurs, dans un quartier défavorisé où aucun blanc ne met les pieds. C'est ici que vivent beaucoup d'indiens mazahuas, une ethnie de l'Estado de Mexico, connue pour ses broderies et ses vêtements colorées. 

MERCI DE VOTRE SOUTIEN ! NOUS COMPTONS SUR VOUS POUR FAIRE PASSER LE MOT AUTOUR DE VOUS !

story:
We are raising money to begin production of our Disaster proof dome homes here in the USA.



The EPS, or Styrofoam domes, have been wildly popular overseas, and are often attributed to MUCH LOWER energy consumption, (50-90%)  and its disaster capabilities.    

 With our funding, we will purchase the necessary equipment, & begin production of the first 800 Units.    This will, in turn, enable us to continue producing the dome structures for the future.     


With the domes, Hurricanes, Tornadoes, Earthquakes, Fire, Flood, Mildew, Mold, and Termites are not an issue.    The oldest dome was built in 126 AD and STILL STANDS to this day, a testament of the Dome Shape's Longevity!



Our plan is to begin production in May 2015.    With your donation, not only will we house the world, BUT will create jobs.   Please, join us in being The Shape of The Future!



You can learn about the domes at our website, www.styrodome.com

story:
What is a Bricks and Minifigs?

Bricks and Minifigs is a retail franchise with 11 locations across the country.

At a Bricks and Minifigs, you can:

  • Buy, sell, and trade new, used and discontinued sets
  • Purchase individual Minifigures or pieces
  • Buy bulk Lego bricks
  • Host Lego-themed events like birthday parties, corporate gatherings, or engineering classes utilizing Lego products
  • Enjoy the company of fellow Lego enthusiasts!

Funding

We need $130,000 to open our franchise. This covers the franchise fee, inventory and all start-up costs.

Why do we want to open a Bricks and Minifigs?

We fell in love with this franchise the moment we walked into the Kailua, Hawaii location. My husband, Jason, was fast approaching the end of his service contract in the Air Force, and we instantly knew this was how we wanted to spend the rest of our working years. We want to work side-by-side and put smiles on people’s faces by providing excellent products, wonderful services and a place for Lego enthusiasts of all ages to call home.

Why we're crowdfunding:

We’ve saved $50,000 on our own, we’re debt free, have credit in the 800’s, but the banks are still hesitant to loan us the $100,000 we need. For many, it’s just too low a number. Some want to see it on the SBA approved franchise list before they’ll act. Others insist we both have second jobs (after my husband's service contract ends in April) before they’ll lend us the money. How they expect us to work full time AND open a business is something I’ll never understand.

If we can crowdfund at least $50,000, we can secure a personal loan for the remaining balance.

Other ways to help:

If you can't contribute, please consider helping by:

  • Keeping us in your thoughts and prayers.
  • Getting the word out any way you can!
  • Sharing this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
We are opening a Bricks and Minifigs store! We are so excited to be turning our passion into a business that will bring families together.  

What is Bricks and Minifigs?

We are your one stop shop for all things Lego! Here are some of the services and products our store will offer.

  • New and used Lego sets
  • Individually sold minifigures
  • Loose bricks
  • Birthday Parties
  • Build Your Own Minifigure
  • Building Classes 

We look forward to seeing creativity and inspiration shape the minds of children and adults in our community.  It is a dream to be able to start a business that will be a place for families to have fun while spending quality time together.  We need help raising funds for start up expenses to get the store up and running. Some of these expenses include store fixtures and inventory.

Watch the video on what Bricks & Minifigs is all about. Watch Video
www.facebook.com/BAMLouisville/videos/455464247...

Other ways to help:

If you can't contribute, please consider helping by:

  • Getting the word out any way you can!
  • Sharing this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
About SORA COWORKING

Hi, I'm Shoka.  This is Yogni, my amazing partner.  We live in Cúcuta, Colombia and opened a very first coworking space in the city, SORA COWORKING, last year.

      

Cúcuta is located in the northeast part of Colombia and situated on the border with Venezuela. Colombia has beautiful nature, fruits, people, culture and not to mention one of the best coffee in the world.

However, I have realized that there is not much space here in Cúcuta for people, both locals and internationals, to sit and work under safe and relaxing situation.  Houses or cafeterias are  wonderful places to work, but sometimes you can encounter various distractions or difficulties. That is why I decided to open a coworking space here.

Not only Sora Coworking is giving a positive impact to the locals (Colombians), but also to internationals. Since Cúcuta is close to Venezuela, and Venezulea has been struggling with economic, institutional, and social crisis for about 10 years and Cúcuta has been one of the main gates for them to enter. According to UNHCR, over 5 million Venezuelans have left the country, which is about 15% of its population. Due to this situation and for the pandemic as well, there are numerous NGOs/NPOs who are striving every single day to help people who are in need.

     

The campaign is important to me and locals because we need space with fundamental materials, including safety, with relaxing environment in order for us to be innovative, creative and interactive.

 

What We Need

￥150,000(1,500USD) to cover the advertisement including the payment for web designers or system engineers.

   

￥300,000 (3,000USD) to cover the first 3 months rent and expenses.

￥350,000(3,500USD) to cover the tech, furniture, and decor. We are going to repair/reconstruct to make sure the place is secured.

　 　 

 

The Impact

We believe there are various impacts we can bring to Cúcuta and the world by this campaign.

First of all, we are offering space that is secure and relaxing to the locals who want to start new business, to organize an event, to have an presentation, to do networking, or even to study or relax. Majority of them need the space which they can feel comfortable and where they can afford, and Sora Coworking is one of the great option for them.

Second, Sora Coworking is inclusive. We are already receiving messages and calls from various parts of the country in different labor areas. This can make a positive impact for people to get chance and to grow collaboratively.

Our vision is that Sora Coworking is going to be an epicenter of entrepreneurship here in Cúcuta. We would like to open a gate in order for people to take the very first step to make an impact.

             

 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge that we face right now is with financial aspect, especially for the material and for the team.

We started our space last year with a small office, and moved here in March. We opened this new place recently, but our space is already being small. We can see there is a necessity clearly.

In order to Sora Coworking to be an epicenter, we need the place big enough, secure enough and comfortable enough for the people.  Security cameras, locks, tables, internet, air conditioner, lights, there are numerous material is needed. Also the place needs to be well-advertised. We can see the concept of "coworking" is still not well-known in the city, and people are curious about it. Our advertisement team is doing a great job, and hope to expand this opportunity to other web designers as well. 

       

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in Sora Coworking, please follow us on Instagram / Facebook and share the information on your social media.

  @soracoworking     soracoworkingcol
story_txt:
About SORA COWORKING
Hi, I'm Shoka.  This is Yogni, my amazing partner.  We live in Cúcuta, Colombia and opened a very first coworking space in the city, SORA COWORKING, last year.
      
Cúcuta is located in the northeast part of Colombia and situated on the border with Venezuela. Colombia has beautiful nature, fruits, people, culture and not to mention one of the best coffee in the world.
However, I have realized that there is not much space here in Cúcuta for people, both locals and internationals, to sit and work under safe and relaxing situation.  Houses or cafeterias are  wonderful places to work, but sometimes you can encounter various distractions or difficulties. That is why I decided to open a coworking space here.
Not only Sora Coworking is giving a positive impact to the locals (Colombians), but also to internationals. Since Cúcuta is close to Venezuela, and Venezulea has been struggling with economic, institutional, and social crisis for about 10 years and Cúcuta has been one of the main gates for them to enter. According to UNHCR, over 5 million Venezuelans have left the country, which is about 15% of its population. Due to this situation and for the pandemic as well, there are numerous NGOs/NPOs who are striving every single day to help people who are in need.
     
The campaign is important to me and locals because we need space with fundamental materials, including safety, with relaxing environment in order for us to be innovative, creative and interactive.
 

What We Need
￥150,000(1,500USD) to cover the advertisement including the payment for web designers or system engineers.
   
￥300,000 (3,000USD) to cover the first 3 months rent and expenses.
￥350,000(3,500USD) to cover the tech, furniture, and decor. We are going to repair/reconstruct to make sure the place is secured.
　 　 
 

The Impact
We believe there are various impacts we can bring to Cúcuta and the world by this campaign.
First of all, we are offering space that is secure and relaxing to the locals who want to start new business, to organize an event, to have an presentation, to do networking, or even to study or relax. Majority of them need the space which they can feel comfortable and where they can afford, and Sora Coworking is one of the great option for them.
Second, Sora Coworking is inclusive. We are already receiving messages and calls from various parts of the country in different labor areas. This can make a positive impact for people to get chance and to grow collaboratively.
Our vision is that Sora Coworking is going to be an epicenter of entrepreneurship here in Cúcuta. We would like to open a gate in order for people to take the very first step to make an impact.
             
 

Risks & Challenges
The biggest challenge that we face right now is with financial aspect, especially for the material and for the team.
We started our space last year with a small office, and moved here in March. We opened this new place recently, but our space is already being small. We can see there is a necessity clearly.
In order to Sora Coworking to be an epicenter, we need the place big enough, secure enough and comfortable enough for the people.  Security cameras, locks, tables, internet, air conditioner, lights, there are numerous material is needed. Also the place needs to be well-advertised. We can see the concept of "coworking" is still not well-known in the city, and people are curious about it. Our advertisement team is doing a great job, and hope to expand this opportunity to other web designers as well. 
       
 

Other Ways You Can Help
If you are interested in Sora Coworking, please follow us on Instagram / Facebook and share the information on your social media.
  @soracoworking     soracoworkingcol

story:
Carl G Wargaming's Story

 

I'm Steve White, and I am the Owner and General Manager of Carl G Wargaming Inc.  I have been playing board games, miniature wargames, role playing games, and collectible card games for a long.......long........time.  I've also been a professional painter of miniatures at different points in my life, like this one I did for a painting contest....

I have been working for the Canadian Armed Forces (CAF) since 1998 in a profession where I am able to build communities and care for the members and families in their most difficult times, and our nation's contribution to the war in Afghanistan meant that I was in high demand.  It all took its tole, and now I am preparing for a medical release due to the injuries I sustained in the service to my country. 

(as a side note, I would have included some pictures of myself in uniform, but this would violate Section 291 of the National Defense Act (NDA), since a crowdfunder is seen as a commercial purpose).

My family and I took many months to decide what I would do after the military, and we kept coming back to my passion for community building and playing games.  Community building was why I joined the  CAF in the first place, and my passion for games has been with me my whole life, so we decided to start a game store back home in the Maritimes. 

We wanted to keep our connection to the military, so setting up our first store by CFB Gagetown seemed a natural choice.  There I will be building a community by setting up a game store that is in Oromocto itself, and which has the space to host large groups of game enthusiasts.  I know that games of all sorts are immensely popular to those associated with the military, and the "recce" we did in September 2019 found us the best location for it.

This will be a big step for my family, and the store will need strong support from the community to be a success, as well as being the game store you always wished for.  Even before COVID-19 hit, getting this business off the ground and well stocked with the games you want was going to be challenging, but now with the pandemic raging we need your help all the more.  The funds raised here will get us the shelving and game tables we need. (No-one likes having to play Settlers of Catan on the floor, or looking for product stacked in big heaps).  

What Your Support Will Mean...

It will mean the difference between having a store that is run by a caring newly retired military member, in a military town, and running event around the military time schedule.  This means planning our events and activities around the APS, Ex Maple Resolve, and large deployments.  It means providing a place for you to gather casually outside of the base.  It means building a strong game community in Oromocto with the expectation that this would follow with you to other military towns across Canada.  We are very happy to have our civilian customers as well, and in a way you will be supporting your troops by being a part of this community, and by supporting a business that is being started by a veteran.  Finally, it would mean the difference between this store succeeding or failing....its just that simple during this health crisis.  

Why open now....its a freekin' pandemic out there?

When we signed our lease, hooked up the power and heat, and made other commitments in December 2019, expecting to open by the end of May,  we were just like every other Canadian at the time....just going along, business as usual.  The bad timing of this virus has left us with some hurdles to jump and is forcing us to be patient as we wait for contractors, banks, suppliers, and medical release moves to all start up again so we can get this place opened.  

How much do you need and what do I get?

We have set an initial goal of $10,000, but any we get over this means the more products, staff, and events we will be able to start up with right away.  It is set as a flexible goal, so if we don't make it to the goal, it will still help.  It just means that more is taken off the top by this crowdfunding platform if we do not achieve the goal.  This means that your dollar will go farther if we do meet and exceed the goal!

With respect to perks, I have tried to make them all interesting so that no matter what your get, it will be unique and memorable.  Whether this is being ordained as a priest of Cthulhu, getting a set of pretty dice (mmmmmm......more dice), or having a vote in what game lines we stock, we want you to start feeling like this is a game store made for YOU!  

Risks & Challenges

To be honest, this is a big risk for us (my family).  We are stepping away from everything I trained for and worked at for the last 20 years, right when my kids are finishing school and looking to college (tuition gives me nightmares already).  But we have done our homework, taken the courses, and found a community that wants what we are bringing to them.  We are "all in" and committed to making this a successful community-building business.  And the more successful this campaign is, the less risk of us stumbling as we do this "about-turn-on-the-quick-march" of my career.

Other Ways You Can Help

I realize not everyone can help financially, or perhaps you can but want to do more!  Here are some suggestions:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo's share tools and let other know about this!
  • Spread the word on your bases and communities, especially in Gagetown, that Carl G Wargaming is on its way!
  • Tell anyone being posted to Gagetown during this weird APS to check us out once the restrictions are lifted.
  • Share, share, and more share on social media!
  • Support us when we open, because that is just as important as supporting us now.

Who is this Carl guy anyway?  I thought your name was Steve?

Though many of you who are in the military would know the answer to this question, your families and others not in the military are probably in the dark on this one.

The name “Carl G” is a slang term that all Canadian Army (if not all Canadian Armed Forces members) would be well acquainted with.  It is a term of affection Canadian soldiers give to the Carl Gustaf Recoilless Rifle (what some might call a “bazooka”).  Developed in Sweden by Saab Bofors Dynamics (formerly Bofors Anti-Armour AB) and entering service with their armed forces in 1948, it started being used in the Canadian Army in 1965 and is still the primary section level anti-tank recoilless rifle used today (all-be with newer models replacing the old over the last 50+ years).  It is rugged, reliable, and has remained effective by adapting to changes in the military environment.   We like the name because it means different things to different people....and honestly, I am fine if you want to call me Carl anyway.  At least I didn't name it "wet-weather boots."

story:
Mi Canasta Orgánica 

Mi Canasta Orgánica is a community farming project that aims to improve the lives of farming families by connecting the abundant production of organic produce in La Merced del Potrero with trade opportunities in the region. 

Based on Oaxaca's coast, this project was born at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic as a means to address the growing economic difficulties in the region. A group of women from the mountain community of La Merced del Potrero came together, calling themselves "Mi Canasta Orgánica". These 16 women began collecting, transporting and trading organic produce on a weekly basis; providing an alternative source of organic products in the tourist destination of Bahías de Huatulco,

Currently, Mi Canasta Orgánica conducts sales by two means:

  • Direct sales in four locations every Tuesday, led by the entrepreneurial “Las Señoras de Rosa" (Ladies in Pink)
  • Home-delivery CSA-style baskets delivered directly to customers' door step 

Traditional, organic agriculture is the main economic activity of La Merced del Potrero, and it is facing increasing opposition from industrial agriculture.

In order to thrive, this initiative needs innovative, market-enabling tools such as online ordering, social media presence, and share the organic farming process with consumers. We seek to use this campaign to level the playing field, and include La Merced de Potrero as another actor in the local produce market. 

 

What do we need? 

With the funds raised through this campaign, we want to invest in two pillars of the project:

1. Generate new sales channels and strengthen those that already exist.
This includes:

  • Improve conditions of the Tuesday points of sale to protect the sellers and customers from the elements.

  • Develop a "next-week harvest" inventory system to project the products available by season and generate a weekly pre-sales menu. 

  • Implement a social media strategy to raise awareness of the realities in farming communities, create transparency of the community's organic agricultural practices, and promote the different trade channels.

2. Coordinate production cycles throughout the community, promote technology, and strengthen organic production practices and increase production volume.
This includes:

  • Create a production calendar to organize planting and harvesting cycles, linked to the sales projections.

  • Set up a demonstration farm to share best agricultural practices and demonstrate techniques to extend the season and get the most production on a single bed.

  • Set up a greenhouse to start seeds and provide seedlings to increase the volume of production and the variety of products.

  • Establish a seed bank to collect and redistribute organic seeds, create production autonomy and increase adaptation & resiliency of seeds.

We aim to implement these initiatives in the next 6 months, including more families and local producers in the trade of their harvest in the process.

 

The growth opportunity 

In Huatulco, most of the fruits and vegetables offered in supermarkets and markets come from Puebla or the Oaxaca Central Market. This requires the transport of between 300 km and 600 km, not counting the transport from the points of production to the centers of distribution. Yet, the availability of organic produce in formal stores is non-existent.

In February, we conducted a survey with Huatulco consumers, where 67% of respondents said they were interested in buying organic products, and only 5% knew how to access them.

Today, according to current sales, Mi Canasta Orgánica supplies a little over 80 families in La Crucecita. The strategy for creating new channels includes:

  1. Increasing door-to-door sales for conscious consumers, who are unaware of where or how to get organic products, or simply do not have time to visit the points of sale on Tuesdays.
  2. Establishing sales commitments with local restaurants that are interested in using organic and sustainable ingredients in their dishes. There is an increasing need for differentiation between restaurants and hotels. Sustainable tourism and conscious chefs demand quality products that we can be provide as part of this project.

 

Thank you for your support!
We look forward to sharing the fruits of the labor of everyone involved.

story:
About us

Manchuria Estate is a private family business located in Nagoya Japan. We just started our business in 2020, and we're hosting guests from all over the world on Airbnb. This is our first challenge on Indiegogo, because we've decided to fight against COVID-19!

Toga's House #1

The founder started hosting at his own house. He selected some furniture at a local store and transformed his room into a French Style listing on Airbnb. Because Paris is the city he spent his honeymoon with his wife, he wants to share the sweet memories with his guests.

Toga's House #2

The first listing on Airbnb goes well, so he purchased other items at the local furniture store again. This time, he made his second room Brooklyn Style. Because NYC is the destination he wants to run his real estate business someday, and he never gives up his dreams!

Toga's House #3

Although our world is pandemic, Manchuria Estate will turn this crisis into a new chance, we purchased an old house in the neighborhood and will transform it into a Mykonos Style Villa. So we started our first campaign on Indiegogo for fundraising of the renovation fee. 

Superhost

The founder has been Superhost 14 times on Airbnb. We've got 4.9 ratings for Toga's House #1#2, and 217 reviews from our guests all over the world. This is the best medal for us.

ARIGATO

ARIGATO means Thank you in Japanese. Thank you for reading our story above, and we really appreciated your generosity in support of Manchuria Estate. Your pledge of 10 USD is great support for us to build our Mykonos Style Villa - Toga's House #3.

Stay

If you'd like to pledge 50 USD or 100 USD, you can stay at Toga's House for one night or two nights. Toga's House #1#2 is the starting point of our family business, and you will have a home feeling stay experience with the founder and his family here.

Nagoya

When people talking about Japan, you may hear Tokyo and Osaka. But where is Nagoya? Nagoya is just on the mid-point between Tokyo and Osaka. I promise you will have a different experience there, and I'm proudly to introduce our beautiful castles, shrines and parks.
